About me

Im a Highly Motivated software developer that loves learning new and more complex concepts.

My introduction to coding and software development was the curriculum on TheOdinProject.com, FreeCodeCamp.org and the book Head First JavaScript. These recources were very helpful with setting up a development environment repeating the principles learned and doing projects to ensure these skills stick with you.

After gaining these skills I began working at OneReach.AI on 10-10-2021 as a Fullstack Developer. I worked on many projects for big companies like
McGraw Hill and Athena Health.

I live in Stafford, Texas with my fiancée and spend most of my free time skateboarding, programming, or playing video games

Projects

Fullstack MERN Application

This is a Create, Read, Update, Delete app created with the MERN stack, which includes MongoDb, ExpressJS, ReactJS, and NodeJS. I wrote the frontend and backend of this app in the first two weeks of 2024. This was my first time using a NoSQL Database instead of using postgreSQL.

This application allows the user to sign-up or sign-in and add a location to the app. This sign in includes Authorization using JSON Web Token and the password on the DB is encrypted using bcryptJS.

When signed in the user can Create a new 'place', Update or Delete their existing 'places'. The user can also open up a Google Maps view of any place on the app using the Google API.

If the user is not signed in they can still view other users 'places' and see them on the map.

Solving a System Persistence issue using Amazon S3 Cloud Storage

I had a previous bug within the backend. Heroku as a service will shut down the server occasionally. Once servers reset the images stored will be deleted.

Ive fixed this by using Amazon S3 Cloud Storage so all pictures used are uploaded to Amazon S3 instead of using FS from Node to save them to the Heroku Server. Now when the servers are temporarily shut off due to inactivity I can continue using files uploaded by users.

See Live

Writing an Interpreter in Go

By recommendation from a popular Programming Streamer The Primeagen and my appreciation for high quality educational books, I purchased Writing an Interpreter In Go

Following along with the book using Go I created an Interpreter for the Monkey Programming Language.

The book covers

Lexing, creating the Lexer using Lexical Analysis, Defining our Tokens, and writing the Lexer along side of Tests to confirm the output

Parsing, starting with simpler tokens like "let" and "return" statements and then parsing complex expressions using Top Down Operator Precedence or Pratt Parsing. The most interesting part of this section is the handling of Prefix and Postfix operators, and handling the Order of Operations for properly parsing an expression like "3 + 4 -5 * 5" to be nested properly as "(3 + 4)((-5) * 5)"

Evaluation, we nearly have our REPL built. In this section we build a Tree Walking Interpreter, create our Object system, Evaluate expressions, Binding variables to the Environment and reflect on how lucky we are to have Garbage Collection handled by Go.

Extending the Interpreter, now that we have a REPL we extend some capabilities of the Interpreter, this includes Arrays, Hash Maps, and adding built in functions.

Expressed as a list of features, the Monkey language has the following:

• C-like syntax

• variable bindings

• integers and booleans

• arithmetic expressions

• built-in functions

• first-class and higher-order functions

• closures

• a string data structure

• an array data structure

• a hash data structure

Source Code

Rest API built with Go

This is an API built using Go and SQLite3. I wanted to build a backend project using something different from Node.js and I really liked using Go previously for the Monkey Interpreter.

Libraries Used

• Gin library which was very helpful for HTTP request routing.

• jwt-go for Auth tokens in requests to verify users.

• bcrypt for encrypting and decrypting passwords stored in the SQL DataBase.

• go-sqlite3 for running the SQL server.


API Requests Supported


GET Requests

api/events

• Get a list of available events

api/events/21

• Get a specific event based on ID


POST Requests

api/events (Auth Required)

• Create bookable event

api/signup

• Create a new user

api/login (Returns Auth Token)

• Sign in and Authenticate user

api/events/21/register (Auth Required)

• Register the user for an Event


PUT Requests

api/events/21 (Auth Required) (Only by Creator)

• Update an existing Event


DELETE Requests

api/events/21 (Auth Required) (Only by Creator)

• Delete an Event by ID

api/events/21/register (Auth Required)

• Delete a registration for an Event



More detailed information on the API can be found in the ReadMe File if you click the link or images!

Tetris Game in React.Js

A Tetris app created with React, as a way to challenge my understanding of React hooks by creating Custom React Hooks in a game more complex than ive ever made, some of my favorite features of the game include handling collision detection and the use of 2D arrays to declare the shape of each Tetromino.

IOS App with SwiftUI

A Create Read Update Delete app built in Xcode with SwiftUI, You can create lists of projects that have objectives to do within them. There are customizable priority and color options for each project. I really appreciate the way SwiftUI makes it easy to include many accessibility options into an application.

Source Code

Rock Paper Scissors Web App

A game of rock paper scissors you can play against an ai opponent, most of the function of this app is a randomizer for your opponents next choice and showing the results by removing and adding css classes with javascript and keeping track of your score against the ai opponent.
